{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3684981,"name":"Michael","username":"LightspeedLazer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lightspeedlazer/{size}/167596_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-19T23:16:43.246Z","cooked":"

Hello CD!

I’m working on improvements to our vision system and one of those improvements is camera pipeline switching. In doing so I saw that PhotonPipelineResult has no way of retrieving which pipeline index the result was produced on. With PhotonCamera.getAllUnreadResults returning up to 20 pipeline results since the last time it was called, it might* have the possibility of containing results from different pipelines (see image)

image1513×603 63.1 KB

As you can see, the second getAllUnreadResults would probably* return 3 results from pipeline 0 and 3 results from pipeline 1. This is where my question comes in: how does PhotonVision handle this situation? There are a couple of possibilities that initially come to my mind:

  • It doesn’t. The situation as described plays out in the way described by the image
    • In this case, the only way to separate the pipeline results would be to make an additional NT subscriber to the pipelineIndexState to get the timestamp of when the response was sent by the coprocessor, and split the pipeline results using that timestamp
  • The results queue is cleared when PhotonCamera.setPipelineIndex is called, as to not mix pipeline results and all results returned match the index returned by PhotonCamera.getPipelineIndex
    • In this case, the second getAllUnreadResults returns just the 3 results from pipeline 1
    • I am unsure as to how this would work, as I don’t think there is a way of “unpublishing” a value from NT and I don’t see any indication that PhotonCamera.setPipelineIndex messes with the results subscriber
  • I have no clue what I am talking about and this isn’t an issue

Now, if the first case is correct, may I request that the pipeline index is retrievable through PhotonPipelineResult to avoid this interesting scenario?

That’s a great observation! It looks like it was raised before but never addressed. This looks like a relatively simple first issue, if you’d be interested in taking it on. Otherwise, we’ll try and get around to fixing it when we have a chance.
